An occurrence of something (countable instances) in large numbers, happening suddenly or in a short period of time; a volley, a barrage.The classical fencer landed a flurry of hits on her opponent.The think piece provoked a flurry of media responses for the remainder of the week.'
A flute is a musical instrument that you blow into to make sound.
To move through the air without touching the ground
A foal is a baby horse.
The plural form of foal; more than one foal.
Fog is a cloud that is close to or on the ground and sometimes prevents a person from being able to see.
A foil is a sword used in the sport of fencing.
If you fold something thin such as paper, you bend it so it touches itself.
The past tense and past participle of fold.
Folk are people.
The plural form of folk; more than one folk.
If you are fond of something, then you like it a lot.

fondness (countable and uncountable, plural fondnesses)
the quality of being fond
Food is what people and animals eat for nutrition or pleasure when they are hungry.
A fool is a person who does or thinks stupid things.
The past tense and past participle of fool.
Unwise. A person who is foolish does not have good sense or judgement. They do things without thinking carefully; they do things that are bad ideas.
The lowest part of the leg, below the ankle; the part of the body used to stand on.
Football refers to a number of team sports in which players kick a ball including association football , American football, Canadian football, Australian rules football, and rugby football.
shows that something belongs to something else, or has a specific function
If you forbid someone from doing something, you do not allow them to do it; you disallow it.
Foreign means something that comes from a different place or country. Foreign people are known as foreigners.
A forest is an area covered with many trees, and sometimes by bushes and other plants.
When you forget something, you have no memory of it.
An instrument for eating, with 3 or 4 sharp points called tines, all in the same direction.

The number 40.

The number 4. Four is one more than three and one less than five.
Fourteen is the even number that is after thirteen and before fifteen. In numerals, it is 14.
The fourth thing is something that is number four  in order.
A small wild animal that is like a dog.
The plural form of fox; more than one fox.

foyer (plural foyers)
A lobby, corridor, or waiting room, used in a hotel, theater, etc.We had a drink in the foyer waiting for the the play to start.
The crucible or basin in a furnace which receives the molten metal.
(Britain) A hostel offering accommodation and work opportunities to homeless young people.
When a person is frail, he is weak and easy to break down physically and mentally.
The parts of a building that are strong and that hold the other parts up.

Any small spot or discoloration.
If something is free, it does not cost money to buy.

freight (uncountable)

Transport of goods.They shipped it ordinary freight to spare the expense.
(figuratively) Cultural or emotional associations.A wedding ring is small, but it has massive emotional freight.
An event is frequent if it happens many times in a short time.
If you do something frequently, you do it often.
If something is fresh it is not old, it is new or like new. Often this means not spoiled or rotten.
The plural form of friend; more than one friend.
If you frighten somebody, you make them feel afraid.
The third-person singular form of frighten.

b'frill (plural frills)
A strip of pleated material used as decoration or trim; a ruffle.
(photography) A wrinkled edge to a film.
A luxury.
Something extraneous added for effect.1977,  Agatha Christie,  chapter 4, in  An Autobiography, part II, London: Collins, ISBN 978-0-00-216012-4:Mind you, clothes were clothes in those days. [\xe2\x80\xa6]\xc2\xa0 Frills, ruffles, flounces, lace, complicated seams and gores: not only did they sweep the ground and have to be held up in one hand elegantly as you walked along, but they had little capes or coats or feather boas.

A small hopping amphibian.
The plural form of frog; more than one frog.
When something is from someone, the person gave or sent it.
Frost is a cover of thin ice on things. Some of these are tree branches, plants, leaves, wires, poles, cars, rooftops, or windows. Frost is like dew, only frozen. Frost can be light or heavy.

A frown is a facial expression whereby the eyebrows are brought closer together and wrinkles form on the forehead. A frown usually happens when a person is unhappy, sad or worried, but can also be very focused on doing something.
The past tense and past participle of frown.
The present participle of frown.
The past tense of freeze.
or  The fruit is the part of a plant or tree that holds the seeds. It's usually sweet and good to eat.
If you frustrate someone, then you make him annoyed or upset.
If you fry something, you cook it in a pan on a stove with hot oil.
Fudge is a kind of chocolate that usually comes in squares.
A container is full of things if there are many of the things in the container and no more can go in.

fullback (plural fullbacks)
(American football) An offensive back whose primary jobs are to block in advance of the halfback on running plays and for the quarterback on passing plays.
(field hockey) A defensive player who assists the goalie in preventing the opposing team from scoring.

To touch something nervously.
The third-person singular form of fumble.
A fume is a gas or a vapor that has a strong smell, or is dangerous to inhale.
If you have fun, you enjoy something.
A fund is an amount of money kept for a specific purpose.
Funny things keep people interested and can make people laugh.
A fuse is a length of cord that will burn and is used to set off explosives.

Too much activity, worry, bother, or talk about something.

(nautical) A long, slender ship propelled primarily by oars, whether having masts and sails or not; usually referring to rowed warships used in the Mediterranean from the 16th century until the modern era.
(Britain) A light, open boat used on the Thames by customhouse officers, press gangs, and also for pleasure.
(nautical) One of the small boats carried by a man-of-war.
(nautical) The cookroom or kitchen and cooking apparatus of a vessel or aircraft; sometimes on merchant vessels called the caboose.
An oblong oven or muffle with a battery of retorts; a gallery furnace.

A unit of volume: eight pints, commonly used for measuring gasoline.
If you gamble, you take a risk.
The third-person singular form of gamble.
A game is something that people do to have fun.
A gang is a group of criminals that work together. These criminals are often called gangsters.
A gap is a difference in the level of two groups.

A garden is a place where flowers and other plants grow where people want them to. Frequently it is a small place with a wall around it, near a house. It may have rocks and other things in it to look beautiful.
A gas is a substance, such as air, that is not liquid or solid.

A gate is like a door in a fence. It opens to let people go through the fence.

A gay person is usually a man sexually attracted to males; also a woman attracted to females.

.
When someone gazes at someone, they stare at that person for a long time.
Gear is clothing and other equipment, especially in sports.
A gem is a piece of mineral that is used in jewelry because it looks pretty.
Usual; about most things. An idea is a general idea if it's about many things or about most things, not just about one specific thing.
A generator is a machine that makes electrical energy from mechanical energy.

b'genius (plural geniuses or genii)
(eulogistic) Someone possessing extraordinary intelligence or skill; especially somebody who has demonstrated this by a creative or original work in science, music, art etc.1898,  Winston Churchill,  chapter 1, in  The Celebrity:In the old days, to my commonplace and unobserving mind, he gave no evidences of genius whatsoever. A gentle person is kind and careful not to cause damage, pain, or surprise.
A gentleman is a man that treats other nicely, or a man of higher class.
If something is genuine, it is what is says it is and not something else; it is not fake.
Geography is how a place is on a map. It is about where things like rivers, mountains, cities, and countries are.
Geology is the science that studies the earth. In geology you might learn about how mountains are made or how continents move. This is sometimes used for similar things on other planets.
A kind of mathematics that is about shapes and spaces.

geranium (plural geraniums)
Any flowering plant of the genus Geranium, the cranesbills, of family Geraniaceae.
The common name for flowering plants of the genus Pelargonium.
A bright red color tinted with orange, like that of a scarlet geranium.geranium colour:
To start to have; to take. When one person gives something, the other person gets the thing.
The third-person singular form of get.

Like a ghost in appearance; death-like; pale; pallid; dismal.Samuel Taylor Coleridge (1772-1834)Each turned his face with a ghastly pang.Thomas Macaulay (1800-1859)His face was so ghastly that it could scarcely be recognized.

Thomas Macaulay (1800-1859)His face was so ghastly that it could scarcely be recognized.

Cartilage; now especially: cartilage present, as a tough substance, in meat.1979, Monty Python, Always Look on the Bright Side of LifeWhen you're chewing on life's gristleDon't grumble, give a whistleAnd this'll help things turn out for the best...
1979, Monty Python, Always Look on the Bright Side of LifeWhen you're chewing on life's gristleDon't grumble, give a whistleAnd this'll help things turn out for the best...
(figuratively, from obsolete scientific theory) Bone not yet hardened by age and hard work.1849, Herman Melville, Redburn. His First Voyage,And it is a hard and cruel thing thus in early youth to taste beforehand the pangs which should be reserved for the stout time of manhood, when the gristle has become bone, and we stand up and fight out our lives, as a thing tried before and foreseen; for then we are veterans used to sieges and battles, and not green recruits, recoiling at the first shock of the encounter.1859, George Eliot, Adam Bede,Look at Adam through the rest of the day, as he stands on the scaffolding with the two-feet ruler in his hand, whistling low while he considers how a difficulty about a floor-joist or a window-frame is to be overcome; or as he pushes one of the younger workmen aside and takes his place in upheaving a weight of timber, saying, "Let alone, lad! Thee'st got too much gristle i' thy bones yet"; or as he fixes his keen black eyes on the motions of a workman on the other side of the room and warns him that his distances are not right.1885, Ada Sarah Ballin, The Science of Dress in Theory and Practice,It. must be borne in mind that the bones of a young infant are little more than gristle, and are liable to bend, and so become deformed.1896, Arthur Conan Doyle, Rodney Stone,"The young 'un will make his way," said Belcher, who had come across to us. "He's more a sparrer than a fighter just at present, but when his gristle sets he'll take on anything on the list.

(transitive) To hack (cut crudely)ShakespeareSuffolk first died, and York, all haggled o'er, / Comes to him, where in gore he lay insteeped.1884: Mark Twain, The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn, Chapter VIIII catched a catfish and haggled him open with my saw, and towards sundown I started my camp fire and had supper. Then I set out a line to catch some fish for breakfast.
ShakespeareSuffolk first died, and York, all haggled o'er, / Comes to him, where in gore he lay insteeped.

Hail is ice that falls from the sky.
Hair is long, very thin, soft material that grows on people and animals.
A half is 1/2 of a whole; 50%.
A hall is a large space with a roof and walls. It can be a kind of large building, or a room or part of a building. Most commonly, it is the area just inside the front door.
When someone halts something, they make it stop.
A ham is the thigh and buttock of any animal used for meat.
The plural form of ham; more than one ham.
Your hands are the parts of your body at the end of your arms. A hand has four fingers and a thumb.
The past tense and past participle of hand.
The plural form of handle; more than one handle.
The present participle of handle.
The plural form of hand; more than one hand.
A handshake is when two people hold hands for a few seconds and move them up and down before letting go. It is often used like a greeting  or to say that two people have agreed on something.
If something is handy, it is easy to use, or useful.
When you hang things, you suspend them in the air using rope, wire, or some other means.
if something happens, it starts or changes without a plan.
Happiness is the emotion of being happy; joy.
When you feel happy, you feel positive, usually because something nice has happened.
A harbor is some water in a curve of land where it's safe for boats because there are no big waves.
If something is hard, it is not soft.
If you harden something, then you make it hard, stiff, or make it more resistant.
Not much, very little.
Tools and supplies needed to build and repair things.
Harmony is when two or more notes sound good at the same time.

harp (plural harps)
(music) A musical instrument consisting of a body and a curved neck, strung with strings of varying length that are stroked or plucked with the fingers and are vertical to the soundboard when viewed from the end of the bodyAny instrument of the same musicological type.
Any instrument of the same musicological type.
(colloquial) A harmonica.
(Scotland) A grain sieve.
(heraldry) A heraldic representation of the musical instrument used as a charge, as in the arms of Ireland.
When someone is harsh, that person is very unpleasant, rough and cruel.
The third-person singular form of have.
Hash is a kind of chopped meat and vegetable that are mixed together.

hasp (plural hasps)
A clasp, especially a metal strap fastened by a padlock or a pin; also, a hook for fastening a door.
A spindle to wind yarn, thread, or silk on.
Alternative form of hesp
An instrument for cutting the surface of grassland; a scarifier.
When something is hasty, it is done in haste, very quickly or in a hurried manner.
A hat is a piece of clothing that you wear on your head.
To hatch from an egg.
If you hate something you dislike it strongly.
The third-person singular form of hate.
When you haul something heavy, you pull it up with big force, or drag with big force.

haunch (plural haunches)

The loin and leg of a quadruped, especially when used as food.
(architecture) A squat vertical support structure.
visits and appears
Someone has something if the thing is in their hands. The person is holding or gripping it.
A hawk is a type of bird that eats meat.
Hay is tall grass that has been cut and dried. Hay is often used to feed animals.
A male person or animal without identifying or describing him. The person is normally identified or described earlier in the text or sentence.
The head is the highest and most important part of the body.
The plural form of head; more than one head.
If a wound  heals it goes away.
If you talk about the health of a person or animal, you are talking about whether they are sick or not.
If you hear a sound, you notice it with your ear.

If you hear something, you use your ears to get a sound from it.
The third-person singular form of hear.
The part of the body that pumps blood.
Heat is a kind of energy. It is the quality things have when they are warm or hot.
The past tense and past participle of heat.
In some religions and myths, heaven is a place where you may go after you die. Heaven is usually seen as a happy place where good people are rewarded.
Heavy is having a lot of weight.

A hoop is a circular or ring-like object.

Johnson, Part 1, Chapter 13, Section 3, pp. 434-435,[1]Besides, various are the paths to power and fame which by accident or choice men pursue, and though they jostle against each other, for men of the same profession are seldom friends, yet there is a much greater number of their fellow-creatures with whom they never clash. 1918, Gerard Manley Hopkins, Untitled poem in Poems of Gerard Manley Hopkins, edited by Robert Bridges, London: Humphrey Milford, p. 83,[4]His locks [\xe2\x80\xa6][\xe2\x80\xa6] like a juicy and jostling shockOf bluebells sheaved in May
(intransitive) To move through by pushing and shoving.1920, F. Scott Fitzgerald, This Side of Paradise, Book One, Chapter 3,[5]Axia and Amory, acquaintances of an hour, jostled behind a waiter to a table at a point of vantage; there they took seats and watched.

(transitive) To be close to or in physical contact with.1859, Charles Darwin, On the Origin of Species, London: John Murray, Chapter 4, p. 114,[6][\xe2\x80\xa6] the advantages of diversification of structure, with the accompanying differences of habit and constitution, determine that the inhabitants, which thus jostle each other most closely, shall, as a general rule, belong to what we call different genera and orders.

(intransitive) To contend or vie in order to acquire something.1819, Walter Scott, The Bride of Lammermoor, in Tales of My Landlord, Edinburgh: Archibald Constable, Third Series, Volume 1, Chapter 1, p. 22,[7]Dick, who, in serious earnest, was supposed to have considerable natural talents for his profession, and whose vain and sanguine disposition never permitted him to doubt for a moment of ultimate success, threw himself headlong into the crowd which jostled and struggled for notice and preferment.1917, Rudyard Kipling, \xe2\x80\x9cThe Children,\xe2\x80\x9d poem accompanying the story \xe2\x80\x9cThe Honours of War\xe2\x80\x9d in A Diversity of Creatures, London: Macmillan, pp. 129-130,[8][\xe2\x80\xa6] Our statecraft, our learningDelivered them bound to the Pit and alive to the burningWhither they mirthfully hastened as jostling for honour.

lieutenant (plural lieutenants)
(military) The lowest commissioned officer rank or ranks in many military forces.(military, US) In the US Army, Air Force and Marines, second lieutenant is the rank below first lieutenant, which is below captain. Both ranks may be referred to as Lieutenant or as the complete forms of the ranks.(military, US, navy) A naval officer whose rank is above that of ensign in the United States Navy and below that of a lieutenant commander. There are two ranks of lieutenant: lieutenant junior grade and lieutenant.(military, US) A commissioned officer in the United States Coast Guard, Public Health Service, or National Atmospheric and Oceanic Administration whose rank is above that of ensign and below lieutenant commander. There are two ranks of lieutenant: lieutenant junior grade and lieutenant.(military, Britain) A naval officer in the Royal Navy who holds the rank above sub-lieutenant and below lieutenant commander.(military, Canada, Australia, New Zealand) A naval officer who holds the rank above sub-lieutenant and below lieutenant commander.
(military, US) In the US Army, Air Force and Marines, second lieutenant is the rank below first lieutenant, which is below captain. Both ranks may be referred to as Lieutenant or as the complete forms of the ranks.
(military, US, navy) A naval officer whose rank is above that of ensign in the United States Navy and below that of a lieutenant commander. There are two ranks of lieutenant: lieutenant junior grade and lieutenant.

(military, Britain) A naval officer in the Royal Navy who holds the rank above sub-lieutenant and below lieutenant commander.
(military, Canada, Australia, New Zealand) A naval officer who holds the rank above sub-lieutenant and below lieutenant commander.

lifeline (plural lifelines)
A line to which a drowning or falling victim may cling to.
A means or route for transporting indispensable supplies.
A source of salvation in a crisis.
(engineering) System or structure of vital importance to a community.
(nautical) On the deck of a boat, a line to which one can attach oneself to stay aboard on rough seas.

lifetime (plural lifetimes)
The duration of the life of someone or something.
(informal, hyperbolic) A long period of time.I've been waiting a lifetime for a train.
Someone lifts something when they use their hands to make the thing go up.
The plural form of lift; more than one lift.

The energy that our eyes sense is light.

Synonyms: photon and energy


Antonyms: darkness and blackness
The comparative form of light; more light.

b'lightly (comparative lightlier or more lightly, superlative lightliest or most lightly)\nIn a light manner.As a teacher, I don\'t take rudeness in class lightly.1907,  Robert William Chambers,  chapter VIII, in  The Younger Set (Project Gutenberg; EBook #14852), New York, N.Y.: D. A flash of light caused by electrical discharge in the atmosphere.
similar or the same
If something is likely, it is probably true or will probably happen.
The third-person singular form of like.
A limb is either a leg or an arm.
A lime is a green citrus fruit that has a sour taste, like a lemon but usually smaller.
The plural form of lime; more than one lime.

limestone (countable and uncountable, plural limestones)
An abundant rock of marine and fresh-water sediments; primarily composed of calcite (CaCO3); it occurs in a variety of forms, both crystalline and amorphous.
The limit is the edge of how far something can go. It can go up to the limit but no farther.
A limp is an irregular gait.
A mark that is long, straight and very thin.
A linear, model, system, relationship, etc. is one where a change in one part leads to a similar change in another part.
The plural form of linen; more than one linen.
,  If you link two or more things, you make a connection between them.
The third-person singular form of link.

lint (usually uncountable, plural lints)
a fine material made by scraping cotton or linen cloth; used for dressing wounds
clinging fuzzy fluff that clings to fabric or accumulates in one's pockets or navel etc.
the fibrous coat of thick hairs covering the seeds of the cotton plant
raw cotton ready for baling
A type of big cat from Africa, India and some of Europe; Panthera leo.
The edge of an opening, especially, the human mouth .

b'liquor (countable and uncountable, plural liquors)
(obsolete) A liquid, a fluid.1665, Robert Hooke, Micrographia:Thus Water also, or any other Liquor, included in a convenient vessel, by being warmed, manifestly expands it self with a very great violence [\xe2\x80\xa6].
1665, Robert Hooke, Micrographia:Thus Water also, or any other Liquor, included in a convenient vessel, by being warmed, manifestly expands it self with a very great violence [\xe2\x80\xa6].
(obsolete) A drinkable liquid.
A liquid obtained by cooking meat or vegetables (or both).
(chiefly US) Strong alcoholic drink derived from fermentation and distillation; more broadly, any alcoholic drink.
In process industry, a liquid in which a desired reaction takes place, e.g. pulping liquor is a mixture of chemicals and water which breaks wood into its components, thus facilitating the extraction of cellulose.'
A list is a group of related words, often in some order, often to help you remember something.
If you listen to something, you try to hear and understand it.
The past tense and past participle of light.
A litre is a measurement of water. 1000 millilitres = 1 litre.
If something is little, its size is not big.
To be alive; to have life.
The plural form of life; more than one life.
A load is something carried, often something heavy.
A block of bread after baking.

b'loam (countable and uncountable, plural loams)
A type of soil; an earthy mixture of sand, silt and clay, with organic matter to which its fertility is chiefly due.1602\xc2\xa0: William Shakespeare, Hamlet, act V scene 1Alexander died, Alexander was buried, Alexanderreturneth to dust, the dust is earth, of earth we makeloam, and of why that loam whereto he was convertedmight they not stop a beer-barrel?
1602\xc2\xa0: William Shakespeare, Hamlet, act V scene 1Alexander died, Alexander was buried, Alexanderreturneth to dust, the dust is earth, of earth we makeloam, and of why that loam whereto he was convertedmight they not stop a beer-barrel?
(metalworking) A mixture of sand, clay, and other materials, used in making moulds for large castings, often without a pattern.'
A loan is money that you borrow and pay back later. Usually, you take a loan from a bank.
A lobby is the entrance of a building.
To find a certain place, location, or destination.
A lock is a metal thing on a door  that stops people from opening the door unless they have the right key to open it.
A locker is a cabinet to keep things in, usually with a lock.
a building in an outdoorsy setting, where people can rent a room
A loft is an attic or a space near the roof of a building.
A log is a piece of wood that is long and round that has been cut off a tree.
The plural form of log; more than one log.
If you feel lonely, you feel sad because you are alone.

If something is long, it takes a lot of time.

Synonym: lengthy


Antonym: short
Someone looks at something when they move their head or move their eyes so that they can see the thing.
The present participle of look.
If something is loose, it moves easily or may come away from what it is attached to.
When you lose something, you don't know where it is.
The plural form of loss; more than one loss.
If you are lost you do not know where you are. You might not know how to get home.

A lot of something is a large amount of it.

Synonyms: much and many


Antonyms: little and a little
The plural form of lot; more than one lot.
If a sound is loud, you can hear it very easily. If it's very loud, it might hurt your ears.

lousy (comparative lousier, superlative lousiest)
Remarkably bad; of poor quality, dirty, or underhanded; mean, contemptible.No offense, but his cooking is lousy.
Infested with lice.
(colloquial, usually with with) Filled or packed (with something, usually bad).The place was lousy with students.She's lousy with credit cards, goes shopping every day!2016, Rick Riordan, The Hammer of Thor, page 6:[I talked to] Annabeth about the Greek gods who hung out in New York and made her life difficult. Apparently North America was lousy with ancient gods. We had a full-blown infestation.

When someone loves another person, they feel good about the person and want the person to be happy.
The third-person singular form of love.
If cost, value, amount, sound, temperature, etc. is low, it is small.
Someone who has good luck is someone who regularly has good things happen to them, almost as if by magic.
If you are lucky, you have a lot of luck.

b'lug (plural lugs)
The act of hauling or dragging.a hard lug
That which is hauled or dragged.The pack is a heavy lug.
Anything that moves slowly.(Can we find and add a quotation of Ascham to this entry?)
A lug nut.Synonyms: lug nut
(electricity) A device for terminating an electrical conductor to facilitate the mechanical connection; to the conductor it may be crimped to form a cold weld, soldered or have pressure from a screw.
A part of something which sticks out, used as a handle or support.
A fool, a large man.Synonyms: big lug
(Britain) An ear or ear lobe.While shaving, the poor sod had a fit and cut part of a lug off.
A wood box used for transporting fruit or vegetables.
(slang) A request for money, as for political purposes.They put the lug on him at the courthouse.
(Britain, dialect) A rod or pole.(Can we find and add a quotation of Wright to this entry?)
(Britain, dialect) A measure of length equal to 16\xc2\xbd feet.SpenserEight lugs of ground.
SpenserEight lugs of ground.
(nautical) A lugsail.
(harness) The leather loop or ear by which a shaft is held up.
A lugworm.
The loop (or protuberance) that exist on both arms of a hinge, featuring a hole for the axis of the hinge'

lullaby (plural lullabies)
A cradlesong, a soothing song to calm children or lull them to sleep.
A lump is a small hard part of something smooth, soft, or continuous.

lumpy (comparative lumpier, superlative lumpiest)
Full of lumps, not smooth.I don't know which was worse, the lumpy soup or the lumpy bed.
Of a water surface: covered in many small waves as a result of wind; choppy.

Lunch is the meal that we eat in the middle of the day.

Synonyms: luncheon, tiffin and dejeuner


Antonym: none
Your lungs are part of your body that is inside your chest. Your lungs allow you to breathe.
;  One verse of a song.

b"mace (plural maces)
A heavy fighting club.1786, The Mace is an ancient weapon, formerly much used by cavalry of all nations, and likewise by ecclesiastics, who in consequence of their tenures, frequently took the field, but were by a canon of the church forbidden to wield the sword. \xe2\x80\x94 Francis Grose, A Treatise on Ancient Armour and Weapons, page 51.
1786, The Mace is an ancient weapon, formerly much used by cavalry of all nations, and likewise by ecclesiastics, who in consequence of their tenures, frequently took the field, but were by a canon of the church forbidden to wield the sword. \xe2\x80\x94 Francis Grose, A Treatise on Ancient Armour and Weapons, page 51.
A ceremonial form of this weapon.1598, I am a king that find thee; and I know 'Tis not the balm, the sceptre, and the ball, The sword, the mace, the crown imperial, The intertissued robe of gold and pearl... \xe2\x80\x94 William Shakespeare, Henvry V, Act IV, Scene I, line 259.
1598, I am a king that find thee; and I know 'Tis not the balm, the sceptre, and the ball, The sword, the mace, the crown imperial, The intertissued robe of gold and pearl... \xe2\x80\x94 William Shakespeare, Henvry V, Act IV, Scene I, line 259.
A long baton used by some drum majors to keep time and lead a marching band. If this baton is referred to as a mace, by convention it has a ceremonial often decorative head, which, if of metal, usually is hollow and sometimes intricately worked.
An officer who carries a mace as an emblem of authority.(Can we find and add a quotation of Macaulay to this entry?)
A knobbed mallet used by curriers in dressing leather to make it supple.
(archaic) A billiard cue."
A machine is a man-made object with moving parts.
If you are mad, you are angry.
The past tense and past participle of make.
Magic has to do with making things happen in ways that are not physical, and might be called supernatural.
A natural object which can attract magnetic objects such as steel or iron.
The plural form of magnet; more than one magnet.

b"magnum (plural magnums or magna)
(wine) A bottle size of 1.5 liters.
(wine) A bottle of wine containing 1.5 liters of fluid, double the volume of a standard bottle.
A firearm cartridge of a large calibre, often derived from a shorter, less powerful cartridge that uses the same bullet.
A handgun that fires a cartridge of this calibre; chiefly a revolver, but rarely an autoloader firing an unusually powerful calibre.1971, Harry Julian Fink, Rita M. Fink, and Dean Riesner, quoted by Clint Eastwood in Dirty Harry:\xe2\x80\x9cI know what you're thinking: \xe2\x80\x99Did he fire six shots or only five?\xe2\x80\x99 Well, to tell you the truth, in all this excitement, I've kinda lost track myself. A maid is someone who cleans a house or other building for someone.
Mail is the messages and packages that you send to other people.
The past tense and past participle of mail.
The main thing is the most important or biggest one.
A major change, problem, event, etc. is a big and important one.
If you make something, you create it.
The third-person singular form of make.

If a person, animal, or plant is male, it cannot have babies or produce eggs. Boys and men are male people.

Antonym: female
A mall is a shopping center where there are many stores that are all in one building.

malt (countable and uncountable, plural malts)
Malted grain (sprouted grain) (usually barley), used in brewing and otherwise.
Malt liquor, especially malt whisky.1896, A. E. Housman, A Shropshire Lad, LXII:Oh many a peer of England brewsLivelier liquor than the Muse,And malt does more than Milton canTo justify God's ways to man.

Maltose-rich sugar derived from malted grain.
A man is a male human.
If you manage something, you organise and control it.

b'mandate (plural mandates)

The mane of an animal refers to the long hair on the neck of a lion or horse.
A maneuver is a type of movement that is usually hard to do.

mangy (comparative mangier, superlative mangiest)
Afflicted with mange.
Worn and squalid-looking; bedraggled or decrepit.We stayed in a really mangy hotel in New York.
Maniac is someone who is crazy. Their mind is not working right.

b'A man.
An adult male human.The show is especially popular with middle-aged men.1599, William Shakespeare, Henry V, act 4, scene 1:The king is but a man, as I am; the violet smells to him as it doth to me.1915, Emerson Hough, The Purchase Price, chapterI:\xe2\x80\x9c [\xe2\x80\xa6] it is not fair of you to bring against mankind double weapons\xe2\x80\x89! b'mistletoe (countable and uncountable, plural mistletoes)
Any of several hemiparasitic evergreen plants with white berries that grow in the crowns of oaks, apple trees and other trees.2014 December 23,  Olivia Judson,  \xe2\x80\x9cThe hemiparasite season [print version: Under the hemiparasite, International New York Times, 24\xe2\x80\x9325 December 2014, p.\xc2\xa07]\xe2\x80\x9d, in  The New York Times\xe2\x80\x8e[1]:[T]he stickiness [of mistletoe berries] persists through the gut, making it hard to defecate mistletoe seeds with any grace. To deal with this, birds like the silky flycatcher, Phainopepla nitens, that are mistletoe specialists, have evolved a "waggle dance"\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x93 also known as butt-wiping behavior\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x93 where they clean up by rubbing themselves against twigs. Indeed, the association with bird droppings may even be the origin of the word: Some evidence suggests that "mistletoe" comes from Anglo-Saxon for "dung on a twig."
2014 December 23,  Olivia Judson,  \xe2\x80\x9cThe hemiparasite season [print version: Under the hemiparasite, International New York Times, 24\xe2\x80\x9325 December 2014, p.\xc2\xa07]\xe2\x80\x9d, in  The New York Times\xe2\x80\x8e[1]:[T]he stickiness [of mistletoe berries] persists through the gut, making it hard to defecate mistletoe seeds with any grace. Indeed, the association with bird droppings may even be the origin of the word: Some evidence suggests that "mistletoe" comes from Anglo-Saxon for "dung on a twig."
A sprig of these plants used as a Christmas decoration.2014 December 23,  Olivia Judson,  \xe2\x80\x9cThe hemiparasite season [print version: Under the hemiparasite, International New York Times, 24\xe2\x80\x9325 December 2014, p.\xc2\xa07]\xe2\x80\x9d, in  The New York Times\xe2\x80\x8e[2]:Mistletoe. The word conjures winter holidays, office parties, stolen kisses, romance. But appreciation of the plant is no modern thing. Kissing under the mistletoe has been happening for at least 200 years. And some 2,000 years ago, the druids in which is now Britain venerated the plant when it grew on an oak. When they found it, they dressed in white, harvested it with a golden sickle, and sacrificed two white bulls. Or so says that great Roman, Pliny the Elder, in his "Natural History."

murmur (plural murmurs)
(countable) Low or indistinct sounds or speech.1874, Marcus Clarke, For the Term of His Natural Life, chapter V:In the prison of the 'tween decks reigned a darkness pregnant with murmurs. The sentry at the entrance to the hatchway was supposed to "prevent the prisoners from making a noise," but he put a very liberal interpretation upon the clause, and so long as the prisoners refrained from shouting, yelling, and fighting--eccentricities in which they sometimes indulged--he did not disturb them.A murmur arose from the audience.1960, P. b"patriot (plural patriots)
A person who loves and zealously supports and defends their country.Alexander PopeSuch tears as patriots shed for dying laws.1901,  Chesterton, G. K.,  The Defendant, page 166:\xe2\x80\x9cMy country, right or wrong\xe2\x80\x9d, is a thing that no patriot would think of saying except in a desperate case. It is like saying, \xe2\x80\x9cMy mother, drunk or sober\xe2\x80\x9d.1953,  Harris, Sydney J.,  \xe2\x80\x9cPurely Personal Prejudices\xe2\x80\x9d, in  Strictly Personal\xe2\x80\x8e[1], Regnery, page 228:The difference between patriotism and nationalism is that the patriot is proud of his country for what it does, and the nationalist is proud of his country no matter what it does; the first attitude creates a feeling of responsibility, but the second a feeling of blind arrogance that leads to war.2013, Simon Jenkins, Gibraltar and the Falklands deny the logic of history (in The Guardian, 14 August 2013)[2]Nothing beats a gunboat. HMS Illustrious glided out of Portsmouth on Monday, past HMS Victory and cheering crowds of patriots. Within a week it will be off Gibraltar, a mere cannon shot from Cape Trafalgar.

(text messaging, Internet) An email or other message sent requesting acknowledgement.I sent a ping to the insurance company to see if they received our claim.

To drop into a liquid, making a sound.
A plot is the course of a story. It is the main things that happen in a story.

b"pluck (third-person singular simple present plucks, present participle plucking, simple past and past participle plucked or (obsolete) pluckt)
(transitive) To pull something sharply; to pull something outShe plucked the phone from her bag and dialled.1900, Charles W. Chesnutt, The House Behind the Cedars, Ch.I:The girl stooped to pluck a rose, and as she bent over it, her profile was clearly outlined.
1900, Charles W. Chesnutt, The House Behind the Cedars, Ch.I:The girl stooped to pluck a rose, and as she bent over it, her profile was clearly outlined.
(transitive, music) To gently play a single string, e.g. on a guitar, violin etc.Whereas a piano strikes the string, a harpsichord plucks it.
(transitive) To remove feathers from a bird.1879, Richard Jefferies, The Amateur Poacher, chapter1:Molly the dairymaid came a little way from the rickyard, and said she would pluck the pigeon that very night after work. She was always ready to do anything for us boys; and we could never quite make out why they scolded her so for an idle hussy indoors. It seemed so unjust.

(transitive) To rob, fleece, steal forciblyThe horny highwayman plucked his victims to their underwear, or attractive ones all the way.
(transitive) To play a string instrument pizzicatoPlucking a bow instrument may cause a string to break.
(intransitive) To pull or twitch sharply.to pluck at somebody's sleeve
(Britain, universities) To reject at an examination for degrees.1847, Charlotte Bront\xc3\xab, Jane EyreHe went to college, and he got\xe2\x80\x94 plucked, I think they call it: and then his uncles wanted him to be a barrister, and study the law\xc2\xa0[\xe2\x80\xa6].

A plug is an object that fills a gap. Examples of a plug are, an electrical plug which plugs into the wall or electrical socket, a sink plug  which stops the water from draining out of the sink or bath.
A fruit that is often a dark red or purple color.
truly vertical
A large feather of a bird.
Plump is a word that is used usually when a person is in the middle of "fat" and "skinny", though not any of them.
The plural form of plum; more than one plum.

plunged
simple past tense and past participle of plunge
You use plus when you add numbers.

plush (comparative plusher, superlative plushest)
(Britain) Very extravagant.
(Britain) Very expensive, or appearing expensive.They lived in a plush apartment complex.
(of a man-made object) Having a soft, fluffy exterior.This plush toy is so cute and soft - I want it!
A pocket is a small empty space, usually in your clothes, usually to carry things in.

podium (plural podiums or podia)
A platform on which to stand, as when conducting an orchestra or preaching at a pulpit.
(sometimes proscribed) A stand used to hold notes when speaking publicly.
(sports and other competitions) A steepled platform upon which the three competitors with the best results may stand when being handed their medals or prize.
(sports) A result amongst the best three at a competition.
A low wall, serving as a foundation, a substructure, or a terrace wall.The dwarf wall surrounding the arena of an amphitheatre, from the top of which the seats began.The masonry under the stylobate of a temple, sometimes a mere foundation, sometimes containing chambers.
The dwarf wall surrounding the arena of an amphitheatre, from the top of which the seats began.
The masonry under the stylobate of a temple, sometimes a mere foundation, sometimes containing chambers.
A poem is a group of words written or spoken as an art. Usually, a poem has a rhythm. Many poems rhyme , and some poems repeat the same first sound in a word .
A poet is someone who creates poetry. If you write poems you are being a poet.
The art of writing poems.
A point is a position with no size, or a small dot.

pointless (comparative more pointless, superlative most pointless)
Having no point or sharp tip; terminating squarely or in a rounded end.a pointless sworda pointless knife
Having no prominent or important feature, as of an argument, discourse, etc.a pointless remarkThe sequel to the film was even more pointless than the original
Having no purpose; purposeless; unable to effect an aim.Since the decision has already been made, further discussion seems pointless.
(mathematics) Without points.a pointless topology
The plural form of point; more than one point.

poise (uncountable)
(obsolete) Weight; an amount of weight, the amount something weighs.1590, Edmund Spenser, The Faerie Queene, I.xii:as an huge rockie clift, / Whose false foundation waues haue washt away, / With dreadfull poyse is from the mayneland rift, / [...] So downe he fell [...].

The weight, or mass of metal, used in weighing, to balance the substance weighed.
That which causes a balance; a counterweight.DrydenMen of unbounded imagination often want the poise of judgment.
DrydenMen of unbounded imagination often want the poise of judgment.
A state of balance, equilibrium or stability.(Can we find and add a quotation of Bentley to this entry?)
Composure; freedom from embarrassment or affectation.
Mien; bearing or deportment of the head or body.
A condition of hovering, or being suspended.
(physics) A cgs unit of dynamic viscosity equal to one dyne-second per square centimeter.

A pole is a long stick that is used for grabbing for support.

Synonym: stick
Someone polishes something when they rub it with a cloth to make it smooth and shiny. Sometimes wax or a special liquid is used.
If you are polite, you treat people nicely and follow the social rules of your group.

b'politely (comparative more politely, superlative most politely)\nin a polite manner1986,  John le Carr\xc3\xa9,  A Perfect Spy:It was night once more and Mary had got through another day without throwing herself politely from a top floor window or scrawling filthy words on the dining room walls.\n1986,  John le Carr\xc3\xa9,  A Perfect Spy:It was night once more and Mary had got through another day without throwing herself politely from a top floor window or scrawling filthy words on the dining room walls.'

polka (plural polkas)
A lively dance originating in Bohemia.
The music for this dance.
A polka jacket.
A poll is a process of asking people for their opinions about something and counting the results.
A pond is a small lake.

pong (plural pongs)
(networking) A packet sent in reply to a ping, thereby indicating the presence of a host.
A pony is a breed of horses that are small in size even when full grown.

Without money; not rich.

Synonyms: penniless, broke, needy, destitute, hard-up, poverty-stricken and impoverished


Antonyms: rich, wealthy, well-off and well-to-do
A frozen flavored ice or ice cream treat on a stick.
If something is popular many people like, love, or enjoy it.

b"porridge (usually uncountable, plural porridges)
A type of thick soup or stew, especially thickened with barley.
(chiefly Britain) A dish made of grain or legumes, milk and/or water, heated and stirred until thick and typically eaten for breakfast.Eat your porridge while it's hot!1922,  Michael Arlen,  \xe2\x80\x9c1/1/2\xe2\x80\x9d, in  \xe2\x80\x9cPiracy\xe2\x80\x9d: A Romantic Chronicle of These Days\xe2\x80\x8e[1]:There were rumours, new rumours every morning, delightful and outrageous rumours, so that the lumps in the porridge were swallowed without comment and the fish-cakes were eaten without contumely.

A port is a place for ships to stop to trade or refuel.

Synonym: harbor

b'portfolio (plural portfolios)
A case for carrying papers, drawings, photographs, maps and other flat documents. [from 1720s]
(by extension) The collection of such documents, especially the works of an artist or photographer.
(politics) The post and the responsibilities of a cabinet minister or other head of a government department. [from 1930s]Synonyms: ministry
(finance) The group of investments and other assets held by an investor. The plural form of port; more than one port.
A position or arrangement.
Post is the letters and parcels that you send to other people.
When you postpone something, it means to cancel a plan or event with the intention of rescheduling at a later date.

postponement (countable and uncountable, plural postponements)
A delay, as a formal delay in a proceeding.The lawyer asked for a postponement in the trial so he could spend more time preparing before it began.
A metal container for cooking. People can cook food by putting the food in a pot and putting the pot on a stove.
The plural form of pot; more than one pot.
To suddenly jump onto something and grab it.
A pound is a unit of currency used in Britain.
The present participle of pound.

pout (third-person singular simple present pouts, present participle pouting, simple past and past participle pouted)
(intransitive) To push out one's lips.
(intransitive) To be or pretend to be ill-tempered; to sulk.
(transitive) To say while pouting.
Powder is the small parts that are made from any dry substance that is pounded, or ground into dust.
Strength, energy, force, control. A quality that can make things happen.
If you practice something, you do it again and again to improve your ability.
A prank is an act to trick or confuse someone; a mean act.
When someone preaches, he gives a speech or sermon before a group of people. This speech is usually related to religion.
If you predict something, you say that it will happen before anyone observes it.
The third-person singular form of predict.
When we prepare something, we get it ready.
The press are the people and organisations that report the news.
The past tense and past participle of pretend.
If something is pretty, people like to look at it.
When you prevent something, you stop it from happening.
A preview is a showing of a work like a movie, play, or painting, before the public are able to see it.

b"prey (countable and uncountable, plural preys)
(archaic) Anything, as goods, etc., taken or got by violence; anything taken by force from an enemy in warSynonyms: spoil, booty, plunderBible, Numbers xxxi. 12And they brought the captives, and the prey, and the spoil, unto Moses, and Eleazar the priest.

The amount of money you need to pay to buy something.
A priest is a person who leads or performs ceremonies in a religion.
The plural form of priest; more than one priest.

b"prim (comparative primmer, superlative primmest)
prudish, straight-laced1986,  John le Carr\xc3\xa9,  A Perfect Spy:God damn it, what does she want of me, this sad, beautiful bridgeplayer of the Fifth Floor, with her air of lost love and her prim carnality? After seven years of her, Brotherhood still had no idea. He'd be out touring the stations, he'd be in Bongabonga land. He'd not speak or write to her for months. Yet he'd hardly unpacked his toothbrush before she was in his arms, demanding him with her sad and hungry eyes.

If something is prime, it is best, most important, most suitable, or in some way number one.
A priority is something that is important; you want to do it first or spend more time or money on it than other things.
A prize is something that you receive for winning or doing well.
The plural form of prize; more than one prize.
If something is probably true, or will probably happen, it means there is a high chance of it.

b'prod (third-person singular simple present prods, present participle prodding, simple past and past participle prodded)
(transitive) To poke, to push, to touch.
(transitive) To encourage, to prompt.2012 January 1,  Michael Riordan,  \xe2\x80\x9cTackling Infinity\xe2\x80\x9d, in  American Scientist\xe2\x80\x8e[1], volume 100, number 1, page 86:Some of the most beautiful and thus appealing physical theories, including quantum electrodynamics and quantum gravity, have been dogged for decades by infinities that erupt when theorists try to prod their calculations into new domains. A profit is money made that is over the total amount spent on the thing being sold.
When you program a computer, you use code to tell the computer what to do.

prom (plural proms)
(Britain) a promenade concert
(Britain, abbreviation) promenade
(US) a formal ball held at a high school or college near the end of the academic year

prophet (plural prophets, feminine prophetess)
Someone who speaks by divine inspiration.Muslims believe that Muhammad was the final prophet sent to mankind.
Someone who predicts the future; a soothsayer.
Prose is words which are not poetry. They can be spoken or written, but they don't have rhythm or rhyme. Most of the time when people use words, it is prose.
If you protect something or someone, you keep it safe; you stop it from being harmed.

protective (comparative more protective, superlative most protective)
Serving, intended or wishing to protect.

protectively (comparative more protectively, superlative most protectively)
In a protective manner.
Protein is a natural substances in food such as meat, milk, and beans.
Someone protests something when they say loudly or strongly that the thing is bad.
When you prove something, you demonstrate that it is for real and true.
When you provide something, you make it available.

b"prowl (third-person singular simple present prowls, present participle prowling, simple past and past participle prowled)
To rove over, through, or about in a stealthy manner; especially, to search in, as for prey or booty.Sir Philip SidneyHe prowls each place, still in new colours decked.Watch the lioness prowling in the shrubbery for zebras.It's tough to sneak vandalism into Wikipedia as there are plenty of other users prowling the Recent Changes page.2011 January 5,  Mark Ashenden,  \xe2\x80\x9cWolverhampton 1 - 0 Chelsea\xe2\x80\x9d, in  BBC\xe2\x80\x8e[1]:While McCarthy prowled the touchline barking orders, his opposite number watched on motionless and expressionless and, with 25 minutes to go, decided to throw on Nicolas Anelka for Kalou.

To idle; to go about aimlessly.That dandy has nothing better to do than prowl around town all day in his pinstripe suit.

prude (plural prudes)
A person who is or tries to be excessively proper, especially one who is easily offended by matters of a sexual nature.1991,  Robert M. Pirsig,  Lila:If you didn't go for Lila you're some kind of prissy old prude. If you did go for her you were some kind of dirty old man.

To look where one is not welcome; to be nosey.
To look closely and curiously at.ShakespeareWatch thou and wake when others be asleep, / To pry into the secrets of the state.
ShakespeareWatch thou and wake when others be asleep, / To pry into the secrets of the state.
Short for psychotic; not able to tell what is real or not.

A place which serves alcoholic and non-alcoholic drinks, and sometimes food. Pub is a short for public house, which is less commonly used.

Synonyms: inn, tavern and bar
Something is public if it is about or for all the people.
If you publish a book, an article, a song, etc. you make it available for other people to buy, read, listen to, etc.
The plural form of pub; more than one pub.
Someone pulls something when they use their hands to move the thing closer to themselves.
The pulp is the part of a fruit that is soft and edible.
To make water or any other liquid move using a machine.
When you punch something, you use your fist to hit it.
The past tense and past participle of punch.

If you punish someone, you cause them to suffer because they have broken a rule.

Synonyms: correct and discipline
A punk is someone who is a bully or someone who is just nasty to people.
A punt is a type of boat.
If something is puny, then it's small or tiny.
A young dog, wolf, fox, seal, shark and some other animals
The plural form of pupil; more than one pupil.
A puppy is a young dog.
The plural form of pup; more than one pup.
;  If you purchase something, you buy it.

A purse is a small bag that is used to carry money.

Synonyms: wallet, handbag and pouch
A pursuit is an act of going after something, to pursue it.
If you push something, you touch it with a force away from your body.
When you put a thing someplace, you move a thing to a place.
A puzzle is a game to try to put pieces together.

pygmy (plural pygmies)

(figuratively) Any dwarfish personEveryone looked like Pygmies whenever giant Joe joined his classmates
(figuratively) An insignificant person, at least in some respectDespite his towering stature, the minister proved a political pygmy
A pyramid is an ancient kind of religious monument shaped with four triangles meeting at the top and being supported by a square or rectangle as its floor.
The sound made by a duck

If you do something quietly, you do it without much noise or in a quiet way.

quilt (plural quilts)

If you quit something, you stop doing it; that is, you do not do it any more.
Very; much.
A small group of questions asked together. Often a quiz is like a small test in school.
To use someone's exact words.
The eighteenth  letter of the English alphabet.
A mammal with long ears.
A race is when people compete to see who is the fastest at either driving or running.
A rack is a series of shelves stacked on top of each other.

A piece of cloth to clean dirty stuff, usually dirty.
A raid is a rapid surprise attack on an enemy.

If it is rainy, it is a wet day with rain.
If you raise something you make it higher; that is you move it up.

Prepared.

A below average class to improve one's skill before advancing to the next level of the class.

remediate (third-person singular simple present remediates, present participle remediating, simple past and past participle remediated)

If two things resemble each other, it means they are similar or look like one another.

respectfully (comparative more respectfully, superlative most respectfully)

A pause or break.

b'restive (comparative more restive, superlative most restive)
Impatient under delay, duress, or control.1914, Bram Stoker, "Dracula's Guest" in Dracula's Guest and Other Weird Stories:The horses were now more restive than ever, and Johann was trying to hold them in.1960,  P[elham] G[renville] Wodehouse,  chapter XV, in  Jeeves in the Offing, London: Herbert Jenkins, OCLC 1227855:\xe2\x80\x9cHullo, Bobbie,\xe2\x80\x9d I said. \xe2\x80\x9cHullo, Bertie,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cHullo, Upjohn,\xe2\x80\x9d I said. The correct response to this would have been \xe2\x80\x9cHullo, Wooster\xe2\x80\x9d, but he blew up in his lines and merely made a noise like a wolf with its big toe caught in a trap. Seemed a bit restive, I thought, as if wishing he were elsewhere. Bobbie was all girlish animation. \xe2\x80\x9cI've been telling Mr Upjohn about that big fish we saw in the lake yesterday, Bertie.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cAh yes, the big fish.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cIt was a whopper, wasn't it?\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cVery well-developed.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cI brought him down here to show it to him.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cQuite right. You'll enjoy the big fish, Upjohn.\xe2\x80\x9d I had been perfectly correct in supposing him to be restive. He did his wolf impersonation once more. \xe2\x80\x9cI shall do nothing of the sort,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, and you couldn't find a better word than \xe2\x80\x9ctestily\xe2\x80\x9d to describe the way he spoke. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is most inconvenient for me to be away from the house at this time. I am expecting a telephone call from my lawyer.\xe2\x80\x9d

b"rhubarb (countable and uncountable, plural rhubarb or rhubarbs)
Any plant of the genus Rheum, especially Rheum rhabarbarum, having large leaves and long green or reddish acidic leafstalks that are edible, in particular when cooked (although the leaves are mildly poisonous).1798,  Thomas Jones,  \xe2\x80\x9cThe Gold Medal, or Thirty Guineas, at the option of the Candidate, being the Premium offered for cultivating the True Rhubarb, was this Session adjudged to Mr. Thomas Jones, of Fish-street-hill, from whom the following Papers were received. Mr. Jones made choice of the pecuniary Reward.\xe2\x80\x9d, in  Transactions of the Society Instituted at London, for the Encouragement of Arts, Manufactures, and Commerce; with the Premiums offered in the Year 1798, volume XVI, London: Printed by W. and C. Spilsbury, Snow-hill. [...], OCLC 912775948, page 213:If every the cultivation of Rhubarb in this kingdom becomes \xc5\xbfo exten\xc5\xbfive as to \xc5\xbfuper\xc5\xbfede the nece\xc5\xbf\xc5\xbfity of its importation; to the Society for the promotion of Arts, Manufactures, and Commerce, will the community be indebted for an advantage, the magnitude and importance of which cannot be too highly appreciated. From whatever cau\xc5\xbfe, which it is unnece\xc5\xbf\xc5\xbfary here to inve\xc5\xbftigate, certain it is the con\xc5\xbfumption of this valuable drug is increa\xc5\xbfed, and continues to do \xc5\xbfo to a very great degree.1839,  John Rogers,  \xe2\x80\x9cRHUBARB.\xe2\x80\x94Rheum.\xe2\x80\x9d, in  The Vegetable Cultivator: Containing a Plain and Accurate Description of All the Different Species and Varieties of Culinary Vegetables; with the Most Approved Method of Cultivating Them by Natural and Artificial Means, and the Best Mode of Cooking Them; Alphabetically Arranged. Together with a Description of the Physical Herbs in General Use, &c. Also, Some Recollections of the Life of Philip Miller, F.R.S. Gardener to the Worshipful Company of Apothecaries at Chelsea, London: Longman, Orme, Brown, Green, & Longmans, Paternoster-Row, OCLC 78055399, pages 265 and 271\xe2\x80\x93272:[page 265] In addition to the qualities of the rhubarb above mentioned, it is allowed by all medical men to make one of the most cooling, wholesome, and delicious tarts sent to table; many persons prefer it indeed either to green gooseberries or apples. In the early part of the season the stalks of rhubarb are cut up and mixed with these fruits; with the former before they have obtained their flavour, and with the latter after losing it by long keeping. [\xe2\x80\xa6] [pages 271\xe2\x80\x93272] Hot-beds, frames, or pits, where a gentle heat can be kept up, will do extremely well for forcing rhubarb, provided the glasses are kept darkened. [\xe2\x80\xa6] The advantages of blanching the stalk of rhubarb are twofold; namely, the desirable qualities of improved appearance and flavour, and a saving in the quantity of sugar necessary to render them agreeable to the palate, as the leaf-stalks when blanched are infinitely less harsh than when growing under the influence of light, in open situations.1999,  J. Heritage; E[mlyn] G[lyn] V[aughn] Evans; R. A. Killington,  \xe2\x80\x9cFood Microbiology\xe2\x80\x9d, in  Microbiology in Action (Studies in Biology), Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, published 2000, ISBN 978-0-521-62111-3, section 5.6.3 (Food Poisoning Associated with the Consumption of Plant Material), page 99:[T]he stems of the culinary rhubarb plant (Rheum palmatum) are used in stewing, jams and in tarts and pies. Rhubarb roots were a traditional purgative and the leaves of the rhubarb plant are rich in oxalic acid. This causes irritation of the mouth and the oesophagus. Ingestion of rhubarb leaves induces vomiting and abdominal pains.2014,  Ruth Rogers Clausen; Thomas Christopher,  \xe2\x80\x9cRheum\xe2\x80\x9d, in  Essential Perennials: The Complete Reference to 2700 Perennials for the Home Garden, Portland, Or.; London: Timber Press, ISBN 978-1-60469-316-4, page 328, column 1:Most Americans are familiar with the culinary rhubarb that furnishes a filling for pies; fewer are aware that rhubarbs also include several bold and beautiful garden perennials. [\xe2\x80\xa6] For a tropical foliage effect on a grand scale, substitute rhubarbs as cold-hardy alternatives to Gunnera; similarly, rhubarbs thrive alongside ponds and streams.

[\xe2\x80\xa6] The advantages of blanching the stalk of rhubarb are twofold; namely, the desirable qualities of improved appearance and flavour, and a saving in the quantity of sugar necessary to render them agreeable to the palate, as the leaf-stalks when blanched are infinitely less harsh than when growing under the influence of light, in open situations.
1999,  J. Heritage; E[mlyn] G[lyn] V[aughn] Evans; R. A. Killington,  \xe2\x80\x9cFood Microbiology\xe2\x80\x9d, in  Microbiology in Action (Studies in Biology), Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, published 2000, ISBN 978-0-521-62111-3, section 5.6.3 (Food Poisoning Associated with the Consumption of Plant Material), page 99:[T]he stems of the culinary rhubarb plant (Rheum palmatum) are used in stewing, jams and in tarts and pies. Rhubarb roots were a traditional purgative and the leaves of the rhubarb plant are rich in oxalic acid. This causes irritation of the mouth and the oesophagus. Ingestion of rhubarb leaves induces vomiting and abdominal pains.
2014,  Ruth Rogers Clausen; Thomas Christopher,  \xe2\x80\x9cRheum\xe2\x80\x9d, in  Essential Perennials: The Complete Reference to 2700 Perennials for the Home Garden, Portland, Or.; London: Timber Press, ISBN 978-1-60469-316-4, page 328, column 1:Most Americans are familiar with the culinary rhubarb that furnishes a filling for pies; fewer are aware that rhubarbs also include several bold and beautiful garden perennials. [\xe2\x80\xa6] For a tropical foliage effect on a grand scale, substitute rhubarbs as cold-hardy alternatives to Gunnera; similarly, rhubarbs thrive alongside ponds and streams.

(Britain, military, aviation, historical) A Royal Air Force World War II code name for operations by aircraft (fighters and fighter-bombers) involving low-level flight to seek opportunistic targets.2009,  Dilip Sarkar,  \xe2\x80\x9cForeword\xe2\x80\x9d, in Brian Lane, Dilip Sarkar, editor, Spitfire!: The Experiences of a Battle of Britain Fighter Pilot, Stroud, Gloucestershire: Amberley Publishing, ISBN 978-1-84868-354-9, page 11:On 13 December 1942, Squadron Leader [Brian] Lane made his first flight from Ludham, a local familiarisation flight. However, such is the insolence of the modern age that these dark fellows dared approach the England penalty box, forelocks untugged, as if demanding instant entry to the Garrick club without having been put up by existing members.

b'romantic (comparative more romantic, superlative most romantic)
(chiefly  historical) Of a work of literature, a writer etc.: being like or having the characteristics of a romance, or poetic tale of a mythic or quasi-historical time; fantastic. [from 17th c.]
(obsolete) Fictitious, imaginary. [17th-20th c.]
Fantastic, unrealistic (of an idea etc.); fanciful, sentimental, impractical (of a person). [from 17th c.]1993 May 16, "Return to New York" Jeeves and Wooster, Series 3, Episode 6:R. Jeeves: In my experience, ladies who spell Gladys with a W are seldom noted for their reliability, sir. It gives them romantic notions.B.W. Wooster: With a W, Jeeves? No, no, no, no. When someone searches for something, they don't know where it is and they look in many places to try to discover where it is.

A season is a particular time of year with a particular kind of weather, usually spring, summer, fall, and winter, or rainy season and dry season.
A seat is something to sit on.
The second thing is the one that is number two  in order.

Hidden or unknown information.
You see something when you look at it with your eyes.
A seed is a small round thing that can grow to be a plant, a flower or a tree.
If you seek something, you want it and search for it.
The way something seems to be is the way you think it is when you look at it, hear about it, think about it, etc.
The third-person singular form of see.
If you seize something, you take it with force and without consent by the owner.
Your self is the type of person you are, particularly the way you usually act, look or feel.

When someone is selfish, that person regards himself/herself as the standard in making decisions.

Antonyms: selfless and unselfish

When you sell something to someone, you give something to someone and the person will give you money for it.

To send something is to make the thing go somewhere without the person. A person sends a letter by putting it in a mailbox. A person can send another person somewhere by telling the person to go there.
The past tense and past participle of send.

The number 7.

seventieth (not comparable)

An act of using thread to make clothes or to mend clothes.
A sewer is a pipe, or system of pipes, that removes wastes from buildings.
A shack is a small shelter; a hut or cabin.
A shackle is a restraint, originally leg-irons which made movement slow and difficult. By extension, it means anything that limits what people do.

If something is shady, it is in or full of shade.

b'sherbet (countable and uncountable, plural sherbets)
A food of frozen fruit juice with a dairy product such as milk added; a sorbet with dairy ingredients.

A traditional West and South Asian sweet drink prepared from fruits or flower petals.1895, Oswald Hutton Parry, Six Months in a Syrian Monastery [2004 reprint], page 86:Tea is becoming a favourite drink in Turkey, not instead of coffee, but of the sherbet or cool drinks that are handed to guests; it comes generally from Russia, and although a trifle dear on account of the carriage, is extremely good, when properly made.2008, Anna Suranyi, The Genius of the English Nation: Travel Writing and National Identity in Early Modern England, page 101\xe2\x80\x93102:The beverages of the Turks were an interesting exception to their reputation for simple foods. While many writers mentioned the Turkish penchant for drinking \xe2\x80\x9ccleere water,\xe2\x80\x9d in light of the prohibitions against alcohol (although some writers, usually those who were more negatively inclined against the Turks, maintained that they were drunkards in secret), virtually all authors discussed the nonalcoholic drinks made by the Turks to replace alcohol, not only coffee, but also sweet refined drinks such as sherbet, a cold drink that usually included sugar, water, and a fruity or flowery flavoring. Sherbet was considered a delicacy, and it and other refined drinks were mentioned in detail by a number of travelers.

b'sill (plural sills)
(architecture) (also window sill) A horizontal slat which forms the base of a window.She looked out the window resting her elbows on the window sill.
(construction) A horizontal, structural member of a building near ground level on a foundation or pilings or lying on the ground in earth-fast construction and bearing the upright portion of a frame. Also spelled cill. Also called a ground plate, groundsill, sole, sole-plate, mudsill. An interrupted sill fits between posts instead of being below and supporting the posts in timber framing.
(geology) A horizontal layer of igneous rock between older rock beds.1980, U.S. Government Printing Office, Geological Survey Professional Paper, Volume 1119Minor palingenetic magmas probably were generated at this time and intruded the mantling rocks in the form of small sills and apophyses; [\xe2\x80\xa6]

Helms Mills, John Bratton, Organizational Behaviour in a Global Context, Page 116A silo is created when members in one department or function do not interact with those in another department, even though there might be operational benefits to the interaction.

skid (plural skids)

A shoe or clog, as of iron, attached to a chain, and placed under the wheel of a wagon to prevent its turning when descending a steep hill; a drag; a skidpan.

A piece of timber or other material used as a support, or to receive pressure.A runner of a sled.In the hours before daylight he sharpened the skids and tightened the lashings to prepare for the long dogsled journey.A ski-shaped runner or supporting surface as found on a helicopter or other aircraft in place of wheels.Due to frequent arctic travel, the plane was equipped with long skids for snow and ice landings.A basic platform for the storage and transport of goods, machinery or equipment, later developed into the pallet.He unloaded six skids of boxes from the truck.(nautical, in the plural) Large fenders hung over a vessel's side to protect it when handling cargo.(Can we find and add a quotation of Totten to this entry?)One of a pair of horizontal rails or timbers for supporting anything, such as a boat or barrel.

(transitive) to clear a liquid from (scum or substance floating or lying on it), especially the cream that floats on top of fresh milkto skim cream
The outer layer of an animal or human.
A skinny person or animal has few flesh or muscle around the skeleton, he/she/it has a thin and narrow body.
An act of overlooking something on purpose.
A skirt is a loose cloth that a woman uses to cover her legs; the lower part of a dress.

skit (plural skits)
A short comic performance.
A jeer or sally; a brief satire.Leslie StephenThat is a mere skit compared with this strange performance.
Leslie StephenThat is a mere skit compared with this strange performance.
(obsolete) A wanton girl; a wench.1936: Like the Phoenix by Anthony BertramHowever, terrible as it may seem to the tall maiden sisters of J.P.'s in Queen Anne houses with walled vegetable gardens, this courtesan, strumpet, harlot, whore, punk, fille de joie, street-walker, this trollop, this trull, this baggage, this hussy, this drab, skit, rig, quean, mopsy, demirep, demimondaine, this wanton, this fornicatress, this doxy, this concubine, this frail sister, this poor Queenie--did actually solicit me, did actually say 'coming home to-night, dearie' and my soul was not blasted enough to call a policeman.

A skull is the bones that make up the head and face.
A skunk is an animal that releases a strong odour when frightened.
The sky is what you see when you look up when you're not inside. It's blue with clouds in it. At night it's black with stars in it.
A skyline is the silhouette of a building or city as seen on the horizon.

b'slab (plural slabs)
A large, flat piece of solid material; a solid object that is large and flat.1859, John Lang, Botany Bay, or, True Tales of Early Australia, page 155,There were no windows in the inn. They were not required, since the interstices between the slabs suffered the wind, the rain, and the light of day to penetrate simultaneously.1913, Jack London, John Barleycorn, 2008, page 14,Then there was the Mexican who sold big slabs of chewing taffy for five cents each.2010, Ryan Humphreys, The Flirtations of Dan Harris, page 73,\xe2\x80\x9cThe pier? You mean those few sodden logs tied together and that dingy slab of rough concrete.\xe2\x80\x9d

A paving stone; a flagstone.

A bird, the wryneck.
(nautical) The slack part of a sail.
(slang) A large, luxury pre-1980 General Motors vehicle, particularly a Buick, Oldsmobile or Cadillac.
(surfing) A very large wave.2009, Bruce Boal, The Surfing Yearbook, SurfersVillage, page 31,After being towed into a massive slab, Dorian dropped down the face and caught a rail, putting him in a near-impossible situation.2011, Douglas Booth, Surfing: The Ultimate Guide, page 95,In August 2000 he successfully rode a slab of unfathomable power at Teahupo\xe2\x80\xb2o.

(computing) A sequence of 12 adjacent bits, serving as a byte in some computers.

If something is slack, it hangs loose and is not held tight.
The third-person singular form of slack.

slain
past participle of slay
If you slam a door or window, you close it hard so that it makes a loud noise.
The third-person singular form of slam.
A long thing is slanting when one end is higher up than the other end and also further along. To be on an angle or sloping.
When you slap someone, you use something to hit another person, usually with something flat.
The present participle of slash.
The killing of animals is slaughter.
A slave is a person who is owned by a master and who works for that master, but receives no—or almost no—money.
The plural form of slave; more than one slave.

sled (plural sleds)
A small, light vehicle with runners, used, mostly by young persons, for sliding on snow or ice. (A "sled" in this sense is not pulled by an animal as a "sleigh" is.)The child zoomed down the hill on his sled.
(US) A vehicle on runners, used for conveying loads over the snow or ice. (contrast "sleigh", which is larger)"Mush!" he yelled at the dogs pulling the sled.
(slang) A snowmobile.

sleek (comparative sleeker, superlative sleekest)
Having an even, smooth surface; smoothsleek hairDrydenSo sleek her skin, so faultless was her make.
DrydenSo sleek her skin, so faultless was her make.
glossy
Not rough or harsh.MiltonThose rugged names to our like mouths grow sleek.
MiltonThose rugged names to our like mouths grow sleek.
What people do when they rest quietly with eyes shut, usually in bed for many hours at night.

sleepy (comparative sleepier, superlative sleepiest)
Tired; feeling the need for sleep.John DrydenShe wak'd her sleepy crew.
John DrydenShe wak'd her sleepy crew.
Suggesting tiredness.1994, Stephen Fry, The Hippopotamus Chapter 2At the very moment he cried out, David realised that what he had run into was only the Christmas tree. Disgusted with himself at such cowardice, he spat a needle from his mouth, stepped back from the tree and listened. There were no sounds of any movement upstairs: no shouts, no sleepy grumbles, only a gentle tinkle from the decorations as the tree had recovered from the collision.

Tending to induce sleep; soporific.a sleepy drink or potion
Dull; lazy; heavy; sluggish.William Shakespeare'Tis not sleepy business;But must be looked to speedily and strongly.

Quiet; without bustle or activity.a sleepy English village
Sleet is the mixture of rain and snow .

a horse-drawn sleigh
A vehicle, generally pulled by an animal, which moves over snow or ice on runners, used for transporting persons or goods. (contrast "sled", which is smaller)Santa travels in a sleigh.

sleighs
plural of sleigh
The past tense and past participle of sleep.

b'sleuth (plural sleuths)
A detective.1908, Edith Van Dyne (Frank L. Baum), Aunt Jane\xe2\x80\x99s Nieces at MillvilleDo ye want me to become a sleuth, or engage detectives to track the objects of your erroneous philanthropy?

(obsolete) An animal\xe2\x80\x99s trail or track.'
The past tense and past participle of slide.
If something slides, it moves smoothly and easily, usually over a surface.
The third-person singular form of slide.
A slight increase, difference, etc. is a small change.
When someone is slim, they are thin and not fat.
A sling is a device used to support a hurt part of the body.

b'slink (third-person singular simple present slinks, present participle slinking, simple past and past participle slunk or slinked or slank)
(intransitive) To sneak about furtively.c. 1607, William Shakespeare, Timon of Athens, Act IV, Scene 2,[1]As we do turn our backsFrom our companion thrown into his grave,So his familiars to his buried fortunesSlink all away, leave their false vows with him,Like empty purses pick\xe2\x80\x99d; and his poor self,A dedicated beggar to the air,With his disease of all-shunn\xe2\x80\x99d poverty,Walks, like contempt, alone.1674, John Milton, Paradise Lost, Book 9[2]Back to the thicket slunk the guilty serpent.LandorThere were some few who slank obliquely from them as they passed.1922,  Michael Arlen,  \xe2\x80\x9c3/1/1\xe2\x80\x9d, in  \xe2\x80\x9cPiracy\xe2\x80\x9d: A Romantic Chronicle of These Days\xe2\x80\x8e[3]:How meek and shrunken did that haughty Tarmac become as it slunk by the wide circle of asphalt of the yellow sort, that was loosely strewn before the great iron gates of Lady Hall as a forerunner of the consideration that awaited the guests of Rupert, Earl of Kare, [\xe2\x80\xa6] .

b'slit (plural slits)

It was blunt and grey, the nose springing thick and flat from high on the frontal bone of the forehead, whilst his eyes were narrow slits of dark in a tight bandage of tissue.\xc2\xa0[\xe2\x80\xa6].

(vulgar, slang) The opening of the vagina.
(vulgar, slang, derogatory) A woman, usually a sexually loose woman; a prostitute.'

slob (plural slobs)
(informal, disapproving) A lazy and slovenly person.
(derogatory) A lazy, obese person.

slop (plural slops)
(now  historical) A loose outer garment; a jacket or overall.
(in the plural, obsolete) Loose trousers.1603,  John Florio, transl.; Michel de Montaigne,  Essayes, London: Edward Blount, OCLC 946730821:, II.12:Chrysippus said that some Philosophers would in open view of all men shew a dozen of tumbling-tricks, yea, without any slops or breeches, for a dozen of olives.Sir Philip SidneyA pair of slops.

A slope is one side of a hill.
A small space usually used to insert coins through.

b'slouch (plural slouches)
A hanging down of the head; a drooping posture; a limp appearanceHe sat with an unenthusiastic slouch.
Any depression or hanging down, as of a hat brim.The plant hung in a permanent slouch.
Someone who is slow to act.2014, Ian Jack, "Is this the end of Britishness", The Guardian, 16 September 2014:In any case, Scotland has been no slouch at national invention. The Greek temple to commemorate James Thomson wasn\xe2\x80\x99t the only monument raised by the 11th Earl of Buchan, who was a friend and neighbour of Walter Scott, and as great a romancer in his obsession with ruins, battlements and fancy dress.
